channel.title: What makes a good game, good?
channel.description:
Well, I've been thinking about this lately, and my opinion is if the story line is true. When I used to play Call of Duty 4, I never really felt attached to the campaign. I went through and did a bit of research and found out that story line is actually true, and ever since then I respected it.
Having gotten World at War, I'm still trying to find out if there is people such as Private Miller, Sgt Roebuck, etc.
Anyway, your opinion?

item.title: What makes a good game, good?
item.dc:creator: @Zero187 Zero187
item.description:
@Zero187 wrote:

Anything new makes something fun. If I’ve seen it before, it will most likely be boring. FPS’s that are all the same get boring, but when they add cool new stuff (an example is Crysis where you had a super-suit) for you to play with, the game is fun. But if I played another game with a super suit I might not like it as much because I have already experienced it.

item.title: What makes a good game, good?
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

PaulT:

[quote]What makes a good game, good?

In games I look for form over function. If the controls suck, the graphics are terrible, and the game-play is garbage, all can be forgiven in case of mutant monkey ninjas from mercury or whatnot. Games that present compelling universes to explore such as Zork, Escape from Monkey Island, A Grim Fandango, etc… Are more fun to me than games that present a compelling universe where there are just as many boring rules as real life just transposed to digital, like Morrowind, Runescape, Etc…The less rules and the more lively the game-world the better. There should be more games like Beyond Good and Evil and Fable (Peter Molyneux games, basically) that present a world we are familiar with (for example, swords/sorcery/high fantasy world) and then kick it’s ass by letting you do fun stuff, like get married, beat your wife, and then sacrifice her to the dark gods, etc… ;)[/quote]Horray! Someone from there forums who have actually heard of the ol’ LucasArts games. Everyone else is like “WTF IS THAT IT LOOKS OLD ITS SHIT”. Monkey Island is the best fucking game-series ever.

item.title: What makes a good game, good?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

I don’t like storylines anymore, it would have been #1 on my list a few years ago but lately I find myself just skipping the cutscenes and stuff. I can’t get into a game the same way I used to. An exception to this is Dreamfall: The longest Journey. That game has absolutely nothing but storyline, and the storyline wasn’t even that good. But the characters are so awesome especially Crow. I felt like I was emerged into the game at times and it was a total escape from reality.

Now I just like a good combination of eye candy and game play.

item.title: What makes a good game, good?
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Kane., post:3, topic:249325”]I like freedom, versatility, dynamics, a worthy objective and a good story line.

Freedom - Open space, able to control character and move far distances without many boundaries and just a set task.

Versatility - Different ways to approach an objective, with many different items to use.

Dynamics - Needs balance, but is also fun to play because it’s a challenge. Lots of different levels and terrains, as well as weaponry/itinerary.

Worthy Objective - Obviously something that commits to the story line, and that actually makes sense.

Good story line - Speaks for itself imo.[/quote]Played Mirror’s Edge?

Also, my list goes something like this:

  1. Graphics/Physics : It’s sad, but I really can’t enjoy a game if it doesn’t push my system’s graphics abilities. It needs to make my eyes happy :).

  2. Storyline: I’m not always on multiplayer, so an immersing storyline is great. You are correct about the CoD4 storyline, it is very respectable when you read up on how they made it. Also, it is not the case for CoD5

  3. Multiplayer: This one is HUGE for me. 90% of the time I am on my 360, i am on Xbox Live. If the multiplayer is not fun, the game is not fun. CoD4 had a fun multiplayer, but I wish they had made it splitscreen.

  4. Realism: I don’t exactly mean realism like real to an every day life standard, but if it is a shooter, make it realistic. If it is sci-fi, make it a possible future. I hate games that go all of the place in realism.

  5. Controls: Not all games have changeable controller options, so if they don’t, the defaults had better be good.

item.title: What makes a good game, good?
item.dc:creator: @Tenac Tenac
item.description:
@Tenac wrote:

My thought is that if it’s an FPS, then it’s about a lot of action with a plot behind it so it’s not pointless shooting, if it’s an FPS online then it’s a lot of communicating and constant fights. With RPG games, it must be an easy game that everyone thinks they are good at and makes people feel good since they can become better than other players.

I never really thought much of the Call of Duty stories since they all seemed pretty similar and it’s just that you’re given a task to do ___ and you kill a bunch of people while doing it. It’s fun, but I enjoy sci-fi games a bit more than realistic games, GoW and Halo are my favorites. What annoys me about COD games is that they aimed for realism, which means you die in 1 shot and people are hiding in windows, around corners, and it’s a constant camping game.
